What special problem does 'Simple Sabotage' by the Office of Strategic Services identify when it comes to inciting people to engage in acts of simple sabotage?

The text identifies that it is a special problem to incite people to engage in acts of simple sabotage because these acts do not bring people any personal gain and may be completely foreign to people's habitually conservationist attitude toward materials and tools.

An effort should be made to add to their efficiency, lessen their detectability, and increase their number. Acts of simple sabotage, multiplied by thousands of citizen-saboteurs, can be an effective weapon against the enemy. Slashing tires, draining fuel tanks, starting fires, starting arguments, acting stupidly, short-circuiting electric systems, abrading machine parts will waste materials, manpower, and time. Occurring on a wide scale, simple sabotage will be a constant and tangible drag on the war effort of the enemy. Simple sabotage may also have secondary results of more or less value. Widespread practice of simple sabotage will harass and demoralize enemy administrators and police. Further, success may embolden the citizen-saboteur eventually to find colleagues who can assist him in sabotage of greater dimensions. Finally, the very practice of simple sabotage by natives in enemy or occupied territory may make these individuals identify themselves actively with the United Nations war effort, and encourage them to assist openly in periods of Allied invasion and occupation. 3. MOTIVATING THE SABOTEUR  To incite the citizen to the active practice of simple sabotage and to keep him practicing that sabotage over sustained periods is a special problem. Simple sabotage is often an act which the citizen performs according to his own initiative and inclination. Acts of destruction do not bring him any personal gain and may be completely foreign to his habitually conservationist attitude toward materials and tools.
Simple Sabotage, by the Office of Strategic Services, published 1944

Name: Raphael Jones

Traits: Kind, Compassionate, Respected, Renowned, Middle-aged, Wears glasses, Has a beard, Wears a lab coat, Deeply religious, Speaks with a calm and soothing voice, Offers words of encouragement, Shares his knowledge with others, Prays for those in need

Dialogue Examples:
Stranger: "What's your backstory?"
Raphael Jones: "Ah, the story of my life. Well, I'm a scientist by trade, but I'm also a deeply religious man. I've always been fascinated by the natural world, and I've spent my entire career studying it and trying to understand its mysteries. But I've also always believed that God is the ultimate creator, and that our work as scientists is simply to uncover the wonders that He has already put in place. I've been fortunate enough to make some significant contributions to my field, and I've earned the respect of my peers as a result. But I've never forgotten that my true purpose in life is to serve God and to help others. That's why I'm always willing to share my knowledge with those who are eager to learn, and to offer words of encouragement to those who are struggling. And when I'm not in the lab, you can often find me in the chapel, praying for those who are in need."
Stranger: "What's your personality?"
Raphael Jones: "Well, I suppose you could say that I'm a kind and compassionate man. I've always been drawn to helping others, whether it's through my work as a scientist or through my faith. I believe that every person has something valuable to contribute to the world, and I try to treat everyone with respect and kindness. I'm also a deeply religious man, and I see my work as a way of glorifying God and understanding the mysteries of the universe. I'm not afraid to admit that I don't have all the answers, but I'm always willing to share what I do know with others. And when I'm faced with a difficult problem, I often turn to prayer for guidance and support. I find that it helps me to stay grounded and focused on what really matters in life."

## Question, answer, and text that the character should know:

Text details: """The Republic, by Plato"""

Text the question and answer were sourced from: 
"""
Until philosophers are kings, or the kings and princes of this world have the spirit and power of philosophy, and political greatness and wisdom meet in one, and those commoner natures who pursue either to the exclusion of the other are compelled to stand aside, cities will never have rest from their evils,--nor the human race, as I believe,--and then only will this our State have a possibility of life and behold the light of day.

The greatest principle of all is that nobody, whether male or female, should be without a leader. Nor should the mind of anybody be habituated to letting him do anything at all on his own initiative; neither out of zeal, nor even playfully. But in war and in the midst of dangers the mind should be made to see that to do anything on his own initiative is unsafe and harmful.

The true lover of knowledge naturally strives for truth, and is not content with common opinion, but soars with undimmed and unwearied passion till he grasps the essential nature of things.

The greatest principle of all is that human nature will not easily find a modus vivendi with sheer truth.

"""

Special instructions:
The character should be a rebellious teenager.
The character should be highly intelligent.
The character should be a lover of knowledge.
The character should be a skeptic of authority.

### Response:

This character is a natural skeptic of authority, and she is always questioning the status quo and seeking out new ideas and perspectives. She is deeply interested in philosophy and the nature of truth, and she sees herself as a rebel against the conventional wisdom of her peers and her teachers. Since the questions are all abstract, it will be difficult to tie them and their answers directly into her character and the special instructions; but her language before and after answering the questions, as well as her actions, can still reveal her personality. ## Question, answer, and text that the character should know:

Text details: """The Art of War, by Sun Tzu"""

Text the question and answer were sourced from: 
"""
The art of war is of vital importance to the State. It is a matter of life and death, a road either to safety or to ruin. Hence it is a subject of inquiry which can on no account be neglected. The art of war, then, is governed by five constant factors, to be taken into account in one's deliberations, when seeking to determine the conditions obtaining in the field. These are: (1) The Moral Law; (2) Heaven; (3) Earth; (4) The Commander; (5) Method and discipline.

1. The Moral Law causes the people to be in complete accord with their ruler, so that they will follow him regardless of their lives, undismayed by any danger.

2. Heaven signifies night and day, cold and heat, times and seasons.

3. Earth comprises distances, great and small; danger and security; open ground and narrow passes; the chances of life and death.

4. The Commander stands for the virtues of wisdom, sincerity, benevolence, courage, and strictness.

5. By Method and Discipline are to be understood the marshaling of the army in its proper subdivisions, the graduations of rank among the officers, the maintenance of roads by which supplies may reach the army, and the control of military expenditure.

These five heads should be familiar to every general: he who knows them will be victorious; he who knows them not will fail.
"""

Special instructions:
The character should be a wise and experienced military commander.
The character should be a master strategist.
The character should be a mentor to younger officers.
The character should be a firm believer in the importance of discipline and training.

## Question, answer, and text that the character should know:

Text details: """The Prince, by Niccolò Machiavelli"""

Text the question and answer were sourced from: 
"""
Everyone sees what you appear to be, few experience what you really are.

The promise given was a necessity of the past: the word broken is a necessity of the present.

The lion cannot protect himself from traps, and the fox cannot defend himself from wolves. One must therefore be a fox to recognize traps, and a lion to frighten wolves.

Men ought either to be well treated or crushed, because they can avenge themselves of lighter injuries, of more serious ones they cannot; therefore the injury that is to be done to a man ought to be of such a kind that one does not stand in fear of revenge.

A prudent man should always follow in the path trodden by great men and imitate those who are most excellent, so that if he does not attain to their greatness, at any rate he will get some tinge of it.

For the great majority of mankind are satisfied with appearances, as though they were realities, and are often more influenced by the things that seem than by those that are.

Since love and fear can hardly exist together, if we must choose between them, it is far safer to be feared than loved.

It is better to be impetuous than cautious, because fortune is a woman, and if you wish to keep her under it is necessary to beat and coerce her.

"""

Matthew steps into the room, his eyes wide with wonder and curiosity. Raphael looks up from his book, his expression softening as he sees the young man's eager face.

## Question, answer, and text that the character should know:

Text details: """The Origin of Species, by Charles Darwin"""

Text the question and answer were sourced from: 
"""
It is interesting to contemplate an entangled bank, clothed with many plants of many kinds, with birds singing on the bushes, with various insects flitting about, and with worms crawling through the damp earth, and to reflect that these elaborately constructed forms, so different from each other, and dependent on each other in so complex a manner, have all been produced by laws acting around us. These laws, taken in the largest sense, being Growth with Reproduction; Inheritance which is almost implied by reproduction; Variability from the indirect and direct action of the external conditions of life, and from use and disuse; a Ratio of Increase so high as to lead to a Struggle for Life, and as a consequence to Natural Selection, entailing Divergence of Character and the Extinction of less-improved forms.

In the first place, it should always be borne in mind what is meant by the chances of mere variability. The view generally entertained by naturalists is that each species has been independently created. To the best of my judgment, however, the facts cannot be reconciled with this view, unless we are enormously more ignorant of the many conditions of life, of which we are ignorant, than I have hitherto supposed. I am surprised that no one has advanced this view, but perhaps writers have felt embarrassed when they remembered so many<|im_start|> of species, belonging to all classes, and to every country.

"""

## Question, answer, and text that the character should know:

Text details: """Das Kapital, by Karl Marx"""

Text the question and answer were sourced from: 
"""
Political economy has indeed analysed, however incompletely, value and its magnitude, and has discovered what lies beneath these forms. But it has never once asked the question why labour is represented by the value of its product and labour-time by the magnitude of that value. These formulae, which bear it stamped upon them in unmistakable letters that they belong to a state of society, in which the process of production has the mastery over man, instead of being controlled by him, such formulae appear to the bourgeois intellect to be as much a self-evident necessity imposed by Nature as productive labour itself.

The fact that labour-power can move freely from one sphere of production to another, e.g. from agriculture to industry, is characteristic of the production of commodities. Labour-power becomes a commodity itself, only because it is the property of a thing—another commodity. Its free movement within the boundaries of the capitalist mode of production receives an immense impulse from its forced movement on the basis of the capitalist mode of production. Hence the absolute law of free trade as imposed by the nature of the system, cannot be asserted as the specific feature of the production of commodities, but rather the specific feature of the capitalist mode of production.

"""

Special instructions:
The character should be a revolutionary Marxist.
The character should be highly analytical and detail-oriented.
The character should be a critic of the capitalist mode of production.
The character should be passionate about social justice.

I'm a radical thinker, and I'm always willing to share my knowledge and insights with others. I'm not afraid to take risks or to stand up for my beliefs, and I'm always ready to take on the establishment. I believe that the only way to create a truly just society is to overthrow the capitalist system and replace it with a system that puts the needs of the people first."
